tn.text: This is another part of the story of Paul's travels as he goes to Corinth.
Aquila and Priscilla are introduced to the story and verses 2 and 3 give background information about them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
"After these events took place in Athens"
Athens was one of the most important cities in Greece. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:act:17:13|17:15]].
Possible meanings are that 1) Paul happened to find by chance or 2) Paul intentionally found.
Here the phrase "a certain" indicates this is introducing new person in the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])
Pontus was a province on the southern coast of the Black Sea. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is probably sometime in the past year.
This is the name of land. Rome is the capital city of Italy. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Claudius was the current Roman emperor. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:act:11:27|11:28]].

tn.ref: he was of the same trade
tn.text: "he did the same kind of work that they did"
Silas and Timothy rejoin Paul.
"So Paul debated" or "So Paul discussed." He gave reasons. This means that rather than just preaching, Paul talked and interacted with the people.

tn.ref: He persuaded both Jews and Greeks
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "He caused both Jews and Greeks to believe" or 2) "He kept trying to persuade the Jews and the Greeks."

tn.ref: Paul was compelled by the Spirit
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the Spirit compelled Paul" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive|Active or Passive]])
This is a symbolic action to indicate that Paul will no longer try to teach the Jews there  about Jesus. He is leaving them to God's judgment. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: May your blood be upon your own heads
tn.text: Here "blood" stands for the guilt of their actions. Here "heads" refers to the whole person. Paul tells the Jews they are solely responsible for the judgment they will face for their stubbornness if they refuse to repent. AT: "You alone bear the responsibility for your punishment for sin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here the word "he" refers to Paul.
The first word "his" refers to Titius Justus. The second word "his" refers to Crispus.
These are names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names|How to Translate Names]])
A worshiper of God is a Gentile who gives praise to God and follows him but does not necessarily obey all of the Jewish laws.
a layperson who sponsored and administered the synagogue, not necessarily the teacher
Here "house" refers to the people. AT: "the people who lived with him in his house" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "received baptism" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Do not be afraid, but speak and do not be silent
tn.text: The Lord is giving one command in two different ways to emphasize that Paul should certainly continue preaching. AT: "You must not be afraid and, instead, continue to speak and not become silent" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism|Parallelism]])

tn.ref: speak and do not be silent
tn.text: The Lord gives the same command in two different ways to strongly command Paul to speak.  AT: "you must certainly continue to speak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet|Doublet]])
It can be stated explicitly what the Lord wants Paul to speak. AT: "and do not stop speaking about the gospel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: I have many people in this city
tn.text: "there are many people in this city who have put their faith in me" or "many people in this city will put their faith in me"

tn.ref: Paul lived there ... teaching the word of God among them
tn.text: This is a concluding statement for this part of the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_endofstory]])
The unbelieving Jews bring Paul to the judgment seat before Gallio.

Achaia was the Roman province in which Corinth was located. It was the largest city in southern Greece and the capital of the province. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names|How to Translate Names]])
This is the name of a man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This stands for the Jewish leaders that did not believe in Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"came together" or "joined together"

tn.ref: brought him before the judgment seat
tn.text: The Jews took Paul by force to bring Paul before the court. Here "judgment seat" refers to the place where Gallio sat when he made legal decisions in court. AT: "took him so that the governor could judge him at the judgment seat" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Gallio was the Roman governor of the Province.
Here "law" refers to the law of Moses and as well as the Jewish customs of Paul's time.

tn.ref: I do not wish to be a judge of these matters
tn.text: "I refuse to make a judgment about these matters"
Here the word "they" probably refers to the Gentiles at the court. They reacted against the Jews who had brought Paul before the judgment seat. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:act:18:12|18:12]])

tn.ref: Gallio made them leave the judgment seat
tn.text: "Gallio dismissed them from the judgment seat." Here "judgment seat" refers to the place where Gallio sits to make legal decisions in court. AT: "Gallio made them leave his presence in the court" or "Gallio made them leave the court" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This may be an exaggeration to emphasize the strong feelings the people had. AT: "many people seized" or "many of them grabbed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole|Hyperbole]])

tn.ref: So they all seized Sosthenes, the ruler of the synagogue, and beat him in front of the judgment seat
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) the Gentiles beat Sosthenes in the court in front of the judgment seat because he was the Jewish leader or 2) it is possible that Sosthenes was a believer in Christ, so the Jews beat him in front of the court.

tn.ref: Sosthenes, the ruler of the synagogue
tn.text: "Sosthenes" was the Jewish ruler of the synagogue at Corinth. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names|How to Translate Names]])
"repeatedly hit him" or "repeatedly punched him."
This continues Paul's missionary journey as Paul, Priscilla, and Aquila leave Corinth. This seems to indicate that Silas and Timothy remain since it says "he" here and not "we."
Cenchreae was a seaport that was part of the greater Corinth city area. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names|How to Translate Names]])
Here the word "he" refers to Paul.
The word "they" refers to  Paul, Priscilla, and Aquila.
The word "brothers" refers to men and women believers. AT: "left the fellow believers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_gendernotations]])

tn.ref: sailed for Syria with Priscilla and Aquila
tn.text: Paul got on a ship that sailed for Syria. Priscilla and Aquila went with him.

This is a symbolic action that indicates the completion of a vow. This can be stated in active form. AT: "he had someone shave off the hair on his head" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"discussed with" or "debated with"
Here the words "they" and "them"  refer to the Jews in Ephesus.
"saying good-bye to them"
Paul continues his missionary journey.
Phrygia is a province in Asia which is now modern day Turkey. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:act:02:08|2:10]].
"arrived at Caesarea." The word "landed" is used to show that he arrived by ship.
He traveled to the city of Jerusalem. The phrase "went up" is used here because Jerusalem is higher in elevation than Caesarea.
Here "church" refers to the believers in Jerusalem. AT: "greeted the members of the church of Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The phrase "went down" is used here because Antioch is lower in elevation than Jerusalem.
"Paul went away" or "Paul left"

tn.ref: After having spent some time there
tn.text: This speaks about "time" as if it were a commodity that a person could spend. AT: After staying there for a while" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Luke tells what happens in Ephesus with Priscilla and Aquila.
Apollos is introduced to the story. Verses 24 and 25 give background information about him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
This word is used here to mark a break in the main storyline.
The phrase "a certain" indicates that Luke is introducing a new person in the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])

"a man who was born in the city of Alexandria." Possible cities are 1) Alexandria in Egypt on the north coast of Africa or 2) Alexandria on the west coast in Asia. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"a good speaker"
"and he knew the scriptures thoroughly." He understood the Old Testament writings well.

tn.ref: Apollos had been instructed in the teachings of the Lord
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Other believers had taught Apollos how the Lord Jesus wanted people to live" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here "spirit" refers to the entire person of Apollos. AT: "Being very enthusiastic" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"The baptism that John performed." This is comparing John's baptism which was with water to Jesus' baptism which is with the Holy Spirit.
How God wants people to live is spoken of as if it were a road that a person travels. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"correctly" or "more fully"
Here the he words "he," "him," and "his" refer to Apollos. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:act:18:24|18:24-26]])
Achaia was a Roman Province in the southern section of Greece. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:act:18:12|18:12]].
"to go to the region of Achaia." The phrase "pass over" is used here because Apollos had to cross the Aegean Sea to get to Achaia from Ephesus.

The word "brothers" here refers to men and women believers. You can make explicit that these are believers in Ephesus. AT: "fellow believers in Ephesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_gendernotations]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"wrote a letter to the Christians in Achaia"
"those who had believed in salvation by grace" or "those who by God's grace believed in Jesus"
Apollos defeated the Jews in front of other people by his arguments.
"with the strength of his arguments and his skill as a speaker"
